content: The list provides names of independent counsels appointed by the special Division of the Court for Appointing Independent Counsels, United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. It summarizes areas of investigation and results, along with cost information from audits by the Government Accountability Office or Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs reports. The list of independent counsels and special prosecutors includes those appointed by the Special Division of the Court, with some identities kept confidential. Cost information was derived from GAO audit reports on expenditures. The independent counsels and special prosecutors appointed by the Special Division of the Court have incurred a total cost of approximately $228,712,589 as of September 30, 2005. Information on appointments and investigation targets is generally kept confidential unless deemed necessary for public interest or upon indictment. The independent counsels and special prosecutors appointed by the Special Division of the Court have incurred a total cost of approximately $228,712,589 as of September 30, 2005. The statutory provisions for the appointment of independent counsels expired in 1999, but the Attorney General can appoint "special counsels" to conduct investigations and prosecutions on behalf of the United States. Regulations for special counsels were promulgated in 1999. The Attorney General can appoint special counsels to conduct investigations and prosecutions. Cost figures for special counsel investigations have been released, including Robert Fiske's Whitewater investigation costing $6,073,000 and John Danforth's Waco incident investigation costing $15,536,793. Patrick Fitzgerald was designated as Special Counsel to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of a CIA employee's identity in 2003. The Government Accountability Office ruled that expenses for the investigation by Special Counsel Fitzgerald could be paid from the permanent appropriation for Independent Counsels. The total expenses of the office as of September 31, 2005, were $902,118. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, 12 resulted in no indictments, while 8 investigations did return at least one indictment. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, 12 resulted in no indictments. Of the 8 investigations that did return indictments, in 3 instances, no indictment was brought against the principal Government official originally named as the subject. In the remaining 5 investigations where the Federal official was indicted, in 3 cases, the official was either acquitted or had their conviction overturned on appeal. Only two federal officials were convicted or pleaded guilty in the 20 independent counsel investigations. Michael Deaver was convicted of perjury and received a suspended sentence, while Secretary Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was eventually pardoned. Special prosecutors and independent counsels appointed under federal law have included Arthur H. Christy. The independent counsel investigations under federal law included Arthur H. Christy, Gerald J. Gallinghouse, and Leon Silverman. Christy investigated allegations against President Carter's Chief of Staff Hamilton Jordan, Gallinghouse investigated allegations against Carter's national campaign manager Tim Kraft, and Silverman investigated other allegations concerning President. Leon Silverman investigated allegations regarding President Reagan's Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, finding insufficient evidence for prosecution. The investigation cost $318,000. A further investigation in 1985 found no indictments sought, costing $7,200. Jacob A. Stein investigated allegations concerning President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, Edwin Meese. Jacob A. Stein investigated allegations concerning President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, Edwin Meese, finding no basis for criminal charges. The investigation cost $312,000. Alexia Morrison was appointed to investigate allegations of false testimony by former Assistant Attorney General Theodore B. Olson, but found insufficient credible evidence for prosecution. The final report on the EPA "superfund" inquiry found no evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice, with legal obstacles hindering prosecution. The investigation cost $2,141,000. Whitney North Seymour Jr. investigated charges against Michael K. Deaver for violating conflict of interest laws, resulting in his conviction for perjury. Michael Deaver was convicted of perjury on three counts in 1987 and sentenced to three years probation and a $100,000 fine. The independent counsel's final report on the Iran-Contra matter was filed in 1989, costing $1,552,000. Various individuals pleaded guilty to offenses related to the Iran-Contra matter. Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair were convicted of federal offenses, including Thomas Clines, Clair George, and Lt. Col. Oliver North. Other key figures included Alan D. Fiers, Albert Hakim, Robert C. McFarlane, Richard R. Miller, and Air Force Major General Richard V. Secord (Ret.). Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair were convicted of federal offenses, including Thomas Clines, Clair George, and Lt. Col. Oliver North. Rear Admiral John M. Poindexter, National Security Advisor, was convicted of five felonies, but his convictions were overturned due to tainted evidence from immunized congressional testimony. Other persons indicted were Duane Clarridge, Joseph F. Fernandez, and Casper Weinberger, who was later pardoned by President George Bush in 1992. President George Bush pardoned individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair, including Casper Weinberger and Duane Clarridge who were indicted, and Clair George, Elliott Abrams, Alan Fiers, and Robert McFarlane who were found guilty or pleaded guilty. The Independent Counsel's final report on the Iran-Contra matter was filed in 1993, with the investigation costing $47,873,400. James C. McKay was appointed to investigate allegations related to Franklyn C. Nofziger and Attorney General Edwin Meese's conduct concerning Wedtech Corporation. In 1987, Independent Counsel investigated Attorney General Edwin Meese's conduct regarding Wedtech Corporation, financial holdings, conflicts of interest, and the Aqaba Pipeline project. The report concluded that Meese's conduct may have violated criminal laws in certain instances, but no prosecution was warranted. Nofziger was convicted in 1988, but the conviction was overturned on appeals. The investigation led to convictions being overturned on appeals due to technical failures in the original indictment. The cost of the investigation was $2,796,000. Another investigation with a cost of $50,000 resulted in no indictments sought. An independent counsel appointed in 1989 also did not return any indictments, with a cost of $15,000. Arlin M. Adams was appointed to investigate allegations of criminal conspiracy involving favoritism and payments made to officials to influence grants and subsidies in programs of the Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan Administration. No indictment was sought for former Secretary Pierce due to his admissions of mismanagement and corruption, age, health, lack of personal benefit, and conflicting evidence of intent. Several individuals involved in the Department of Housing and Urban Development scandal were found guilty of various crimes, including making false statements, conspiracy, bribery, and money laundering. This included consultants, former HUD officials turned developers, and the United States Treasurer. Cruse, a former Connecticut housing official, was indicted for perjury and obstruction of justice but acquitted by a jury. Philip D. Winn, the former HUD Assistant Secretary for Housing, pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges and was later pardoned by President Clinton. The final report of the independent counsel's office was released in October 1998, with the investigation costing $29,417,318. Michael F. Zeldin succeeded Joseph E. diGenova to investigate whether Janet Mullins violated any laws. Michael F. Zeldin succeeded Joseph E. diGenova on January 11, 1996, to investigate whether Janet Mullins violated federal criminal law regarding the search of Bill Clinton's passport files during the 1992 presidential campaign. Independent Counsel diGenova found no evidence of criminal conduct in the final report filed on November 30, 1995. The investigation cost $3,089,082. Julie F. Thomas succeeded Robert W. Ray on March 12, 2002, succeeding Independent Counsel Kenneth W. Starr. Julie F. Thomas succeeded Robert W. Ray on March 12, 2002, who in turn succeeded Independent Counsel Kenneth W. Starr. Starr was appointed in 1994 to investigate Whitewater allegations involving President Clinton and the First Lady. His jurisdiction was later expanded to include the White House travel office and misuse of power allegations. The independent counsel was appointed to investigate various matters involving the White House, including the firing of staff from the travel office, misuse of FBI files, false statements made by White House Counsel, and allegations of perjury, obstruction of justice, and intimidation of witnesses in the civil case involving President Clinton. Several individuals have pleaded guilty as a result of the investigations. The independent counsel investigations have resulted in guilty pleas and convictions of various individuals, including former Arkansas Governor Jim Guy Tucker. Additional indictments were reinstated by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Independent Counsel Starr obtained an additional 15-count indictment on November 13, 1998. On January 26, 1999, the United States Court of Appeals reinstated indictments against Webster Hubbell for concealment and false statements related to land deals in Arkansas. Hubbell pleaded guilty to tax evasion and false statements charges. Other results of the investigation included acquittals and dropped charges for other individuals involved. Herbert Brancum and Robert Hill faced charges, while Susan McDougal was acquitted on obstruction of justice charges. Julie Hyatt Steele was indicted for perjury and obstruction of justice in the Monica Lewinsky investigation, leading to a mistrial. Independent Counsel Starr announced that Steele and McDougal would not be retried on hung-jury counts. The "Whitewater aspect" of the Clintons' investigation was concluded after a plea bargain with Webster L. Hubbell. In 1999, Independent Counsel Starr stated that the "Whitewater aspect" of the Clintons' investigation was concluded, with no indictments for the President or First Lady. Independent Counsel Ray confirmed in 2000 that there was insufficient evidence to prove their involvement in any criminal conduct related to Madison Guarantee, CMS, or Whitewater Development. Ray also issued reports to the Special Division of the Court regarding FBI file information. The FBI file information (InRe: Anthony Marceca) did not show criminal conduct by White House officials or Hillary Clinton in obtaining derogatory information. Independent Counsel Ray announced no criminal indictments for David Watkins or Hillary Clinton regarding the White House travel office. The report found insufficient evidence for criminal charges. The Special Division of the United States Court of Appeals released a report on October 18, 2000, stating that there was insufficient evidence for criminal charges in the Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones-deposition matter. President Clinton admitted to giving evasive and misleading answers in the Jones civil suit deposition and agreed to a five-year suspension of his law license and a $25,000 fine. President Clinton pardoned four individuals involved in the Arkansas "Whitewater" investigation. Independent Counsel Starr submitted reports reaffirming findings on Vincent Foster's death and forwarded materials to the House of Representatives for potential impeachment grounds against President Clinton. The Independent Counsels investigated potential grounds for impeachment against President Clinton, with costs totaling over $73 million. Donald C. Results of investigations into individuals and companies regulated by the Department of Agriculture included guilty pleas, fines, and settlements related to false statements, campaign contributions, conflict of interest, and gifts to Secretary Espy. Blackley, were involved in various legal issues related to gratuities, money laundering, and campaign contributions linked to former Secretary Espy. Williams, were convicted or found guilty of various charges related to illegal gratuities, false statements, and campaign contributions linked to Secretary Espy. Former Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy was acquitted of three counts of perjury and 35 counts relating to alleged acceptance of gifts. Several individuals involved in the investigation were pardoned by President Clinton. The final report of Independent Counsel Smaltz was filed in January 2001. Barrett was appointed to investigate allegations against former HUD Secretary Henry G. Cisneros. Cisneros was indicted along with Linda (Medlar) Jones, Sylvia Arce-Garcia, and John D. Rosales. Charges against Arce-Garcia and Rosales were dropped, while Jones faced various charges including fraud and money laundering. Former Secretary Cisneros, along with his sister and brother-in-law, pleaded guilty to multiple felony counts related to fraud and money laundering in a house purchase financed by Mr. Cisneros. President Clinton pardoned Cisneros and Linda Jones in 2001. Independent Counsel Barrett's office continued non-investigative tasks until the final report was released in 2004. The final report of Independent Counsel Daniel S. Pearson, appointed to investigate financial dealings of Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, was filed in November 1996. The investigation ended upon Secretary Brown's death, with a total cost of $3,861,710. The investigation into fundraising violations by former White House official Eli Segal concluded with no indictments returned. The total cost of the investigation, including attorneys' fees, was $628,156. Another investigation by Carol Elder Bruce found no criminal indictments regarding false statements to Congress by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt. The total expenditures for this investigation were $7,152,293. Ralph I. Lancaster was appointed to investigate unlawful solicitation of campaign contributions by Secretary of Labor, Alexis Herman. Ralph I. Lancaster was appointed on May 26, 1998, to investigate unlawful solicitation of campaign contributions by Secretary of Labor, Alexis Herman. The final report was submitted on April 7, 2000, with expenditures related to the investigation totaling $6,027,860. Abdul Rahman, a Singapore businessman, was indicted for illegal campaign contributions but was outside the jurisdiction of the United States.
